oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joseph Buckner Killebrew
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: People associated with agriculture; Plantation owners; Farmers' groups; Iron industry; Monuments & memorials; Journalists; Emigration & immigration; Bas-reliefs
Agriculture; Killebrew, J. B. (James Buckner), 1831-1906; Montgomery County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tennessee Agriculture Hall of Fame memorial honoring Joseph Buckner Killebrew. There is included an bas-relief image of Killebrew, and brief details of his life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joseph Buckner Killebrew (1831-1906) was a New South advocate and Tennessee's first Commissioner of Agriculture. In his writings and speeches, he advocated the improvement and extension of public education, encouraged immigration to the South, the development of natural resources for industrialization, and improvement of agriculture, including the break up of large landholdings, the diversification of crops, enrichment of soil, and a program to attract European immigration to farm unoccupied land.
